label.INDCRIME: Percentage who were victims of any NI safe community survey crime

result.label: Indicator - Crime prevalence rate
note:
[b]Crime prevalence rate[/b]

[b]How do we measure this?[/b]
Percentage of people who were a victim of any NI safe community survey crime.

[b]Source[/b]
Findings from the 2022/23 Northern Ireland Safe Community Telephone Survey
[url=Findings+from+the+2022/23+Northern+Ireland+Safe+Community+Telephone+Survey+R+&+S+Bulletin+Findings+from+the+2022/23+Northern+Ireland+Safe+Community+Telephone+Survey+|+Department+of+Justice+(justice-ni.gov.uk)]R & S Bulletin Findings from the 2022/23 Northern Ireland Safe Community Telephone Survey | Department of Justice (justice-ni.gov.uk)[/url]

[b]Impact of Covid-19[/b]
There was a change in survey mode from 2020/21 due to the pandemic and the method by which interviews were undertaken changed from face-to-face to telephone. This resulted in a break in the time series. The change reduced the sample size, particularly for 2020/21. Results for the three latest years are not directly comparable with previous sweeps.

[b]Further Information[/b]
1. The prevalence rate is the estimated percentage of adults who have been a victim of at least one personal crime or have been resident in a household that was a victim of at least one household crime.
2. The Northern Ireland Safe Community Survey was previously known as the NI Crime Survey. Given the change in survey mode as a result of the pandemic, the survey years from 2020/21 are referenced as the Northern Ireland Safe Community Telephone Survey.
3. Previously conducted on an ad hoc basis, the survey began operating on a continuous basis in January 2005.
4. Data is not available prior to 2014/15 as the Local Government District breakdown was not included in the data prior to this.
5. Figures for 2020/21 are not included as a result of the reduced sample size.
6. All other missing data has been suppressed due to small sample sizes (less than 100 respondents).
